There is a multitude of problems with hydrogen FCEVs and some of those were tackled, but others not so much. For example, the safety of refueling stations. In Norway, which is ironically (since it’s a major producer of petroleum) very advanced when it comes to EVs, there has been a series of major explosions at hydrogen refueling stations. It turns out that hydrogen is very volatile. The few stations that exist in California are at hydrogen plants and are rarely used, so we haven’t seen the real effects of implementation at the public retail level.

Toyota meanwhile, is now showing a major change of heart. They’re abandoning FCEVs and embracing BEVs, but with clear hesitance. Their new Toyota bZ4X and the entire future 16 model “bZ” BEV lineup takes a conservative approach by using slow charging and low power discharging to conserve battery life.

So why did they pivot so quickly away from hydrogen?

The biggest issue has been battery storage capacity, their physical size and weight. Charging speed is actually no longer an issue, with extremely fast DC charging and efficient EVSEs out there. The size and weight problems are about to be solved with solid state batteries, which Toyota has been working on for years. They are FAR more energy dense, making them much smaller and lighter than current technologies. That makes ranges of 1000+ miles possible, with car weight below current ICE versions.

Quite simply, the future belongs to battery electric vehicles, not fuel cell vehicles.

10:07 — “if we replace all 15 million cars in CA with [battery] electric cars, the grid would fail.” There is truth in that claim, but it’s ultimately not meaningful.

First, we can’t and won’t roll out BEVs out that fast, so it’s a meaningless hypothetical in the first place.

But more importantly, most people who make such claims, imagine that you have to charge the entire capacity of the battery upon plugging in every evening. That’s extremely unrealistic, because the average American drives about 25 miles/day, after factoring out occasional long road trips, since they’re not charged from home. That’s somewhere around 7.5KWh/day for a typical BEV. The BEVs themselves typically have a 60ish KWh capacity, so you can stagger that by street address, say, or by when overnight the charger kicks in.

In short, HFC is a strong candidate for trucks, possibly airplanes, and trains, but it’s not practical for passenger vehicles, on a nationwide nor worldwide scale. The well-to-wheel efficiency, from renewables, is no better than gasoline.

Honda has had a Home Generation Station for years--it's operational, but not in production. It uses natural gas as a feedstock and produces hydrogen at home to fuel your FCEV, along with meeting your home's needs for electricity and hot water. It is about the size of a large refrigerator and could be installed in your garage.

Better, IMO, is the system designed by the gentleman in NJ (he's on YT) who powers his home, car, lawn mower, etc via hydrogen produced and stored on site using PV cells to crack water into hydrogen. He uses tanks formerly used to store propane to store the hydrogen and then feeds it back into the fuel cell stack to produce electricity as needed. All of his home's electrical needs are met by the system as well as being able to fuel his vehicles. He's commercialized the process in a shipping container-based form factor for remote area use.

Both are greener than mining lithium to make the batteries needed for battery-powered electric vehicles and then charging them with coal and gas fired electrical plants as is currently being done. (Although if we made LFTRs powered by the thorium mined along with the lithium, we'd have all the green power we needed for the next 100,000 years--also on YT, see Kirk Sorenson's video about Thorium.)

Best would be to have enough PV and Thermal solar capacity at your home to power your house, heat your water, make hydrogen to store for the night/fuel your HFC vehicle, and use the stored hydrogen to power your home via fuel cell at night. When thinking about future, CO2 neutral, fossil fuel free energy systems it's crucial to think about reducing our primary energy demand. Two technologies are very noteworthy in this regard:
1. BEV's (battery electric vehicles)
2. Heat pumps

The reason why BEV's reduce the primary energy demand is quite obvious. 7l of gasoline for 100km contains about 70kWh of energy. A BEV on the other hand using only 20kWh for the same distance. So the primary energy demand drops to a third even if we drive the same distance.

Heat pumps are less obvious, since we often think that oil heaters for example are already 98 percent efficient, so how can this be improved? I won't go into the thermodynamics of this, but as a matter of fact the energy demand can be reduced drastically with heat pumps. An oil heater produces less than 1kWh of thermal energy for 1kWh of oil. A heat pump on the other hand produces 3-5kWh of therman energy for 1kWh of electric energy. That means that with heat pumps we can reduce the primary energy demand to a 1/3 or even a 1/5.

These are key technologies for a successfull and intelligent energy transition. We get the same comfort for a lot less energy. This also means that we need less renewable energy sources, which allows us to make the energy transition faster. And of course we need less energy, which is cheaper as well.

You probably won't read this, but i think you really understated the importance of the efficiency massively! Hydrogen fuel cell cars use 2-3 times the energy that a battery electric vehicle would use. In places like germany or switzerland and certainly a lot more places we don't have those 2-3 times more energy in the transportation sector (which makes up a large chunk of the energy demand). That means that in such places the energy transition and thereby the paris climate goals of reaching net zero CO2 emissions by 2040 would be virtually impossible.

That's why regenerative energy systems experts like Prof. Volker Quaschning and many others make it pretty clear that BEV's have to be the future. If fuel cell powered cars become too popular it would endanger the energy transition. To save it we would have to drive 2-3 times less kilometers then with BEV's. Does anyone really want that? The problem become even worse if with e-fuels, since you also need hydrogen for it, but have to process it further, which causes more energy losses and you'll burn it in internal combustion engines, which are highly inefficient. That would mean we'd need about 6 times more energy for the same distance. So that would also endanger the energy transition in case this would spread too much. Or if you want to see it this way: The more inefficient the technologies that we use the longer it will take to complete the energy transition, the more expensive it will probably be and the less we'll be able to do/the more we'll have to give up.

The bottom line is that you can't look at any potential technology that helps us achieve carbon neutrality by itself. You will always have to look at it in the context of the energy system it's working in. Which means that it's crucial to read the scientific literature in regards to 100 percent renewable or CO2 neutral energy systems.

Another thing to consider are EROEIS. Renewables can have quite low EROEIS therefore we have to be carefull when combining renewables with very inefficient technologies. We don't want to end up using more energy then we get back in the form of work i.e. we don't want our energy sources to end up as energy sinks. So if a solar panel has an EROEI of 3 (it hasn't) and i use it to produce e-fuels to drive an internal combustion engine with (losses of over 90 percent), then i won't have gained any energy. I lost energy in the overall process i.e. i made life harder compared to having done nothing.

PS:
I'm not bashing hydrogen by the way. The scientific literautre seems to be quite clear about the fact that we'll have to produce hydrogen to produce some amount of e-fuels and as an long term energy storage system (to deal with the seasonal variability of renewables), but because of the losses it's not a good idea to use them anywhere where it isn't completely necessary. For cars it's not necessary. It would be a huge waste of renewable energy and we already have too little of it and are building renewable energy sources too slowely to stay below 1.5°C of warming. Let's compare the Tesla-3 and the Toyota Mirai.

I’ll use kWh per 100 miles to make the numbers easier to compare.


Tesla-3

The Tesla-3 does 4.4 miles per kWh.
That’s 22.73 kWh per 100 miles driven by the car from the battery

Charging is 94% efficient (some report 99% for 400v chargers).
So that’s 24.18 kWh per 100 miles at the wall socket.

The UK electric grid is 92% efficient at the wall socket (via 5x transformers).

So that’s 26 kWh per 100 miles at the power station.


Mirai

The Mirai does 400 miles on a tank according to Toyota.
(Journalists put it at only 280 miles, but we’ll be generous).

The hydrogen tank on a Mirai has a capacity of 5.6 kg of hydrogen
So the Mirai uses 1.4 Kg of hydrogen per 100 miles.

The energy density of Hydrogen is 33.6 kWh per kg
So the energy used by the Mirai per 100 miles is 47.04 kWh.
(that’s already more than double the Tesla).

I’ll ignore the energy used to go to the local gas station.
So that’s 47.04 kWh at the local gas station.

I'll ignore the truck journey from the power station to the gas station.
So that’s 47.04 kWh at the power station.

BUT the hydrogen is distributed as a liquid in insulated trucks.
Liquefaction consumes more than 30% of the energy content of the hydrogen.
So that’s 67.2 kWh at the power station before it’s liquefied.

Making hydrogen by electrolysis is only 50% efficient.

So that’s 134 kWh as electricity at the power station

That’s 5x worse than the Tesla.

An important thing to mention is that if you live in a high density area, you don't need to actually install a charger at home, you can just charge a BEV from a standard outlet!

Charging from a drier outlet or an installed Level 2 charger will make it recharge faster, sure, but those are only necessary if you really are a heavy driver, or if you have a long commute from a faraway suburb. But if you only drive like 30 miles per day, you most likely won't ever need anything more than a standard outlet, and will only rarely need to fall back on a public supercharger.

Also worth mentioning about fast chargers is that comparing Hydrogen fuel stations to fast chargers without mentioning cost is a huge false equivalency. Building a fuel station is like three orders of magnitude more expensive than installing a charger and requires digging to build underground storage tanks much like gas stations. As a result it is feasible for a chain like McDonalds to mandate that their franchises all install fast chargers at their restaurant parking lots (as is happening like Europe). Now what would it take to fuel 4000 trucks with Hydrogen? 3 times more electricity. Ok, yo can make the hydrogen (and consume the electricity) in advance, not necessarily at the time of fueling like when you charge the batteries, but at the same rate of production, it will take 3 times more time to produce the electricity needed to make hydrogen. So you you load the batteries of 4000 trucks during 8 hours at night at the same time, you will have a peak of load during these 8 hours every night. But to fuel the same 4000 trucks with hydrogen, you will be generating that same "peak" of energy 24 hours a day, 7 days a week (because 8 x 3 = 24). That means that the capacity of generation must be the same for both, and the net consumption of energy is triple for hydrogen. Not only that, as Physics Girl explained, there is not much room to improve on hydrogen production and electricity generation from hydrogen, we are approaching the theoretical limits. However in batteries there are several leads of investigation going on, batteries will get better, live longer, be smaller and lighter, and charge faster. On top of that, expanding / improving the electric generation capacity needs to take place either for hydrogen or batteries, and more so for hydrogen, and on the distribution side improving / expanding the distribution of electricity is easier and cheaper that creating a distribution system for hydrogen, which involves very specialized pipelines (much more complex and expensive than wires) or, even worse, transporting by truck. And... as we move to renewable energies (all or most of which are electrical generation) it makes a lot of sense to remain electric all the time (instead of going from electric to hydrogen to electric). What I mean is that if we are going to keep moving towards electric ovens, ranges, water heaters, home heaters (heat pumps) and cloth dryers, to replace non-renewable gas with renewable electricity, we are going to need to upgrade the electric grid anyway... or produce more electricity at home with solar panels, which is the smartest thing to do... and good luck using that home-produced electricity to generate hydrogen at home. Many, many years ago I was a big fan of the concept of fuel cell vehicles. GM had been developing them for quite some time, and we had one of their development facilities in our area that one of my neighbors worked at as an industrial engineer. It was in 2008 when they finally had a fuel cell vehicle (a Blazer, or something like that, it's been a while) that they passed around to the employees for the purposes of spreading the good word to the public. She brought it over to our house one day and we took it for a spin around the neighborhood (we couldn't spend much time with it, she only had it for the evening). It drove like a regular vehicle, of course, except for the turbine sound of the fuel cell cooling system, which of course made it seem quite futuristic. I was really quite excited about it, just knowing that this would be the future. For posterity, I had my kids pose for a picture in front of it, one of them (of course) standing there with a "gee, dad, this is about the stupidest thing in the world" look on their face.

Fast forward a few years and GM threw in the towel. They hit some pretty significant barriers, one of which was the cost of the fuel cell (largely due to the expense of the platinum it required). I haven't read about the most recent developments of fuel cell technology, and I have to assume that this has been overcome to some degree. But I knew Toyota was still working on it, and I was (in my head at least) cheering them on.

Fast forward to last year and, well, I bought a BEV. There were no FCEVs for me to consider, not in my area at least. The current situation is battery electrics make sense only for city driving, essentially. In large Spanish cities a number of rental companies have sprung up that maintain fleets of electrics that people get in and drive around the city. Keys are digital and sent by mobile, and cars are opened over bluetooth. The average range is about 50km. Computers monitor their location and charge. When they are low the computer removes them from circulation and the company sends out personnel to drive them to nearby charging stations, then puts them back on the road. It works well. They are popular. About half the price of taxis and cheaper than owning a car if you only drive occasionally. They are not without issues, though. First, they tend to charge people by the minute rather than by the kilometre, which leads to unsafe driving. Second, you can't guarantee availability, and depending on traffic patterns vehicles tend to be unavailable when you need them and abundant when you don't. So you might drive to a place and then be "stranded". ;) Despite this, they are very popular, as anyone with a driving licence will prefer them to hailing a cab. Electrics may also make sense for short-range inner-city logistics, loading and unloading, and delivery, generally run by workers on an eight hour shift, or maybe two workers on two shifts for 14-16 hours of operation, and the rest of the time the vehicles are idle - so they can be charged for the next day no problem.

It would be a different story, though, if everyone had a BEV. Even if we had as many electric stations as petrol stations, and people were willing to wait longer, they would just collapse. They are designed for fill-up times of a few minutes. There would be long queues and long waits to access a charging station. We'd need higher capacity if everyone switched. Rental companies can mitigate this essentially by rotating cars in and out of circulation.

Furthermore, the reality is most people in European cities want their private cars for holiday trips and visiting relatives, not city driving. That involves long distance driving. Electrics can also be used for that now with super-charging stations, but their range is short so you need to carefully plan your route from one station to the next and be prepared to wait between charges.

Hydrogen is the only technology that could really substitute petrol cars in terms of range, capacity and convenience. While they take slightly longer to fill up, it's only a small difference, and we can mitigate this by streamlining payment through digital payment platforms - payment in traditional petrol stations takes as long or longer than filling up. So we can more or less get away with just adding hydrogen pumps to existing petrol stations if we're smart about it.

The issue, though, is that this is the CURRENT situation. If, however, there were another battery breakthrough that extended the range of BEV to at least 600 km per charge or beyond and lengthened the lifespan of BEV, then BEV will definitely win. If the range of BEV went to 1000 km on a single charge, it would be no contest. If you can get better batteries with increased energy density to extend the range such that you only have to charge occasionally, and a single charge will get you at least as far as you can go in a single day of driving, then the efficiency of BEV is a no brainer. Li-ion batteries are just not there - but they are tantalizingly close to being there. Just one major breakthrough could be enough to push them into that range.
Battery tech is evolving. We will arrive at a battery that does not require charging and the efficiency is going to eclipse any other fuel source.

Here’s a big problem I have with this: those vehicles are not zero emissions, because nothing ever is, and that makes all the difference in the world.

As you stated yourself, it takes twice as much energy (at least) to power FCEVs as is does for BEVs. This, in turn, doubles the amount of carbon linked to the production of the required electricity, no matter how clean the source is, because it’s never zero. You’re simply never going to get rid of that inefficiency, no matter what you do, because you’re always going to have more steps in the energy conversion process when compared to BEVs, which are already very well optimized for this.

The reason this matters is that this changes the amount of carbon being emitted per kilometer travelled and not flat. In other words, you’re changing the slope of the line that accounts for the total amount of carbon that was emitted since the beginning of the manufacturing process at any given point in time. Given the relatively long life of a typical car, this means the total CO2 emissions of a FCEV over its entire lifetime is likely to be quite a bit higher than that of a BEV for the same usecase. Obviously, here, we’d need to compare the initial intensity of manufacturing to be sure, but I’m ready to bet that they’re similar, and the lifetime emissions are generally dominated by the per-kilometer component anyway.

Unless you can find some other major advantage of FCEVs that’s good enough to justify this discrepancy, this sounds very much like a deal-breaker here. One example of such an advantage would be, for instance, the extreme weight efficiency of fuel cells, which makes them a perfect fit for aircraft, since they are primarily concerned with being lightweight.

In the case of terrestrial vehicles, though, this doesn’t quite work out.

Steam reforming is a hydrogen production process from natural gas. This method is currently the cheapest source of industrial hydrogen. The process consists of heating the gas to between 700–1100 °C in the presence of steam and a nickel catalyst. The resulting endothermic reaction breaks up the methane molecules and forms carbon monoxide CO and hydrogen H2. The carbon monoxide gas can then be passed with steam over iron oxide or other oxides and undergo a water gas shift reaction to obtain further quantities of H2. The downside to this process is that its byproducts are major atmospheric release of CO2, CO and other greenhouse gases.[6] Depending on the quality of the feedstock (natural gas, rich gases, naphtha, etc.), one ton of hydrogen produced will also produce 9 to 12 tons of CO2,

The plastic casing that prevents overheating, the cabling inside, and all other components in a lithium-ion car-battery make up roughly 50% of the weight of such a battery.
The actual lithium is rarely, if ever, recycled. But the lithium is the part that is the most expensive, yet also the most difficult to recycle.

Hey, thank you for this thorough analysis of the topic. One issue I feel got too little attention are the impacts non-mobility markets will have on hydrogen, hydrogen pricing, and, ultimately, the economics of hydrogen mobility. A couple of points to consider:
- Hydrogen is already used in many industrial applications, particularly in the chemical industry. Most of that (~94 %) is fossil hydrogen from methane cracking. Therefore, that legacy use of hydrogen will have to be covered by "green" hydrogen from renewable energy electrolysis.
- There are several applications where hydrogen is the ONLY alternative to how we currently produce stuff, e.g. steel. At the moment, steel is produced using coking coal, which emits a lot of greenhouse gases. The current thinking in the industry is that hydrogen is the only viable alternative to producing steel from iron ore without the use of coke. Luckily, several companies are working on that and Hybrit from Sweden just announced that they shipped a first batch of "green steel" to Volvo using hydrogen.
- As carbon taxes, tariffs, and whatnot rise, i.e. the cost of carbon emissions rises, the economics will swing towards a widespread adoption of hydrogen for many industries outside of mobility.

For these reasons I believe there are several applications for hydrogen outside of mobility markets that will determine the pricing of hydrogen worldwide. These industries, particularly the steel industry, will dominate the demand side and therefore push hydrogen pricing so high that FCEV will not be able to compete against BEV, at least when it comes to passenger vehicles. Nevertheless, I really enjoy driving my institute's hydrogen car, even though I think that will remain an exotic experience.

There are two major issues that I've not seen discussed in these videos.

1. Hydrogen gas is (currently) produced from fossil fuels. It is NOT a clean technology. FCEV are not zero emission. In many countries, a large percentage of the grid electricity is clean - for example, France is ~80% nuclear, and the UK is only 40% natural gas and 0-5% coal.

2. FCEV and BEV completely miss the real solution, which is to radically reduce the dependence on cars. In Europe, if you're near a city you don't need a car - public transport is excellent, and there are enough facilities (shops, banks, hairdressers) within walking distance. We can't fix the climate crisis with new technologies alone. The first and most important solution is to reduce demand, then replace the demand with cleaner options. Public transport will always be far more efficient than the best electric car.
This also goes for the trucks - Ideally these should only be used to cover the last 10-50 miles. Everything else is better carried by rail, which is powered directly from the grid.


BEV also have other advantages. One of the major problems with renewable powered grids are variable supply. If there are thousands of cars plugged into the grid, they can store and return energy to the grid when not in use to even out supply fluctuations, and also only charge at times when demand is below supply.

Also, how much hydrogen is actually made by electrolysis? How much is made from fossil sources? Last: The term Batterry Electric Vehicle, or BEV, is technically incorrect. It is an accumulator vehicle, as it can be recharged. Batteries are single use primary cells. I know that the english language is pretty benevolent when it comes to using the term battery for both primary (true batteries) and secondary cells (accumulators), but this is not the case in other languages. For example, in German, people do not say that the "Batterie" died on their phone, they say their "Akku" (short for accumulator). Same with other electronics like notebooks. But a TV remote control or a wireless mouse/keyboard, which are often powered by single use batteries, need "Neue Batterien", which is technically correct. Also, when it comes to hybrid trolleybuses that can operate off the grid, or even streetcars with their own independent electricity storage for emergencies so they can move out of an intersection if the power fails, we refer to the "traction accumulator", nobody is saying "battery" or "traction battery". The reason is use this wording is to distinguish the traction accumulator from the "regular" accumulator, that operates the 24V circuits and contactors you need in order to connect to the HV system. Even my own electric car has two types of accumulators. The regular 12V lead-acid and then the traction acumulator that stores the energy to move the car. I really dislike the term "battery electric vehicle". When I hear it, I imagine a toy car running on single use batteries.

Love the first question about what it would do to the grid to charge EVs overnight vs fueling with Hydrogen that goes completely ignored.
Well... Making Hydrogen is about 60% efficient, and then using it in a fuel cell is about 80% efficient, so just under 50% of the power produced makes it from the power source to moving the vehicle forward.
Meanwhile, charging a battery EV is ~80% efficient... so about 80% of the energy produced goes into making the vehicle move forward (with all other efficiencies of the production plant, energy transmission, and electric motors in the vehicle being essentially the same).

So to answer that first question: Yeah, if we moved to 100% EVs then it is going to be a large demand on the power grid and we need more production capacity on the grid. But we move to fuel cells then we need 30% more energy produced to do the same amount of work... that is a bit of a logistical nightmare as we electrify everything.

That said, there are some fantastic uses for hydrogen. Particularly, and nearly exclusively in military applications where you want to produce fuel on-site nearly anywhere in the world, and super fast refueling of things like tanks and planes. OR if you have power production with a very large baseline production level like in a nuclear future where we get next gen reactors, or cold fusion reactors that want/need to run at near capacity in order to run most efficient. Then all of the production above electric demand could get dumped into hydrogen production... but then you need to push out all of the infrastructure for deploying that, and hydrogen frankly is not nearly as safe or easy to move around as gasoline is.

I think Fuel Cell + Li-Ion hybrid vehicles would be a great addition to the market. We already have PHEV, which pair Li-Ion with gas. FCEV by themselves still seem to be expensive, so bringing together the technologies of FCEV and BEV to make this new hybrid might be extremely expensive.

But the hybrid mentality is exactly why I still want to purchase a Chevy Volt (PHEV) as my next car. The resilience that you get, like whether the grid fails due to more frequent extreme weather events/a shift in climate (see ERCOT in Texas this past spring) or whether the Canadian tar sands dry up/Saudi Arabia stops selling oil to the US for political reasons/we outlaw shale and deepsea extraction, means less emergencies. Life can still go on. Think of the redundancies engineers employ in cybersecurity, or in fire protection of buildings, or in Uninterruptible Power Supplies used for big data centers at Microsoft or FoxCon. Less failures lessen the loads for all parties involved in acting to get the system back to normal.

I think the short refuel time with FCEVs makes so much sense. With BEVs, yes the grid would be overloaded if we put all vehicles on it immediately, but with electricity you can control the rate of charge. If you plug your car in overnight, electricity can flow both directions at different rates and at different times of the night depending on larger, collective grid statuses (see Vehicle 2 Grid concepts). BEVs can still act as distributed renewable energy storage devices, those of which many people argue are necessary if we want to see renewable generators like Wind and Solar take off and become successful (80-90% grid mixes compared to the 10% today).

I can totally see a future where if you have the time and are not driving your vehicle for hours and hours, say if you're working at home, then through electricity you can employ your car as a distributive energy store for renewables. If you don't have time, then the quick, 5 minute fuel time means the rest of the activities for the day aren't delayed or blocked.

Aside from the safety rules involved, I can totally see hydrogen becoming a 1-to-1 replacement for natural gas. It itself is a gas anyways, and may be able to utilize the same infrastructure. Think I've heard that corrosion is still a problem though. Obviously the cooling is too, but researchers around the globe are working with different messengers/carriers of hydrogen, like ammonia or methanol.

I appreciate the attempt by Dianna to present a balanced take on things, despite some perceived bias/optimism of Toyota employees.
The argument that that BEV's don't work for everyone because of living situation (no garage) vs FCEV is somewhat weak because you can still find electricity anywhere. Coffee shops, mall parking lots. Easy to expand to apartments and more common places. Even street lights have been proposed. Bottom line is the situation is pretty good for a good chunk of people, and getting better by the day. Can't quite put a hydrogen tanks everywhere though, so you'll never be able to get away from making dedicated trips to a station. I agree that Hydrogen can be a part of a healthy and diversified infrastructure, especially for energy storage if you have plentiful excess renewable energy, but I'm still not sold on its use case for commuter vehicles.

More specific to car design, hydrogen might have a weight efficiency vs batteries but it's volumetric energy density isn't great whereas battery tech is improving at a much faster rate. Its storage at pressure also makes it more difficult to package, since you can't hide them under the floor of the passenger compartment. The best user experience, from an ergonomic and aesthetic perspective will be found with BEVs.
